info.name: Umeya
info.catch_phrase:
Gathering place.
People and local communities connection.
Preservation of traditions.

about.title: About
about.desc: Umeya is a place where people gather, connect, and preserve. We will have shared tenants, shared offices, sometimes galleries, and music events, where people can gather and connect with each other. We want to create a place where people can feel at home, and at the same time, we want to preserve our traditions. We hope you will stop by for a moment or a side trip on your day off.

meiji.title: Meiji Era (23th Oct. 1868 – 30th Jul. 1912)
meiji.desc: The main building was constructed in 1902 (35th year of Meiji era), and a ryotei (Japanese-style restaurant) called "Aburaya" was operated.

taisho.title: Taisho Era (30th Jul. 1912 – 25th Dec. 1926)
taisho.desc: Shinzaburo Matsunobu bought the house that had previously been used as the ryotei and began operating a medicine business under the name Umeya, dealing in medicines, dynamite, and other explosives.

showa.title: Shōwa Era (25th Dec. 1926 – 7th Jan. 1989)
showa.desc: It is said that Shinzaburo Matsunobu built a new detached house in 1935.

background.title: Background
background.desc: Umeya was to be a café where people could gather in an old folk house that had been vacant according to the previous owner's plan. However, she passed away halfway through the project, and the plans came to a halt. About fifteen years after the house became vacant, we often visited Yame and interacted with the local people. One day, we heard about this old folk house and decided to make use of it, taking over the owner's desire to create a place for people to gather as she had envisioned at the time.Not only that, but the goodness of the people, the traditional architecture that lines the building, and the vast Yabe River behind Umeya also pushed us to get to know this Kurogi.
